Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 06:01PM - edited Apr 13, 2010 06:03PM by sweatyspice I've been told that 6 weeks is the norm, but I won't actually be starting till about 10 or 11 weeks out. I had a big surgery and wanted to wait a bit longer to heal, so I was going to start 9 weeks out. My rad onc was fine with that, but there was a glitch at my first session and they had to delay another week and a half to re-do the calculations.  I'm a bit worried about having waited this long, as I was ready to start last Monday, but .... there's nothing I can do about it now but hope for the best.  Now I'll (hopefully!) start tomorrow.  My surgery was at the very end of January. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 03:18PM sweatyspice wrote: It seems like you had a "lumpectomy" for a biopsy.  In other words, the purpose of your surgery so far was only to determine whether or not an area of concern was cancerous.  It makes sense to determine whether or not there's cancer there first before removing nodes.  If the area had been benign, node surgery would have been unnecessary.  Your original post said you needed another lumpectomy (or a mastectomy), so I'm assuming they need to go back in and take more tissue to make sure they remove all the cancer and get clean margins - or am I misunderstanding something? What I'm confused about is why they'd do node surgery before you made a decision about mastectomy v lumpectomy.  Seems to me a node surgery could/should be done at the same time as the "real" lumpectomy or mast.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today! Janina sweatyspice

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2009 04:57AM sweatyspice wrote: No imaging test is perfect, but MRI can show some cancers which mammo and ultrasound do not.  I had suspicious calcifications and a mammo-guided stereotactic biopsy.  It came back positive for DCIS.  My surgeon wanted to make sure there wasn't anything else lurking in there that we didn't know about, so I had an MRI.  Usually, nothing else is found but I was one of the unlucky ones; there was another suspicious area.  Since this area could not be seen on mammo, or ultrasound, or felt, the only way to biopsy it was through an MRI guided biopsy - which was basically the same as the mammo guided one, just in a different machine.  Sadly, that area tested positive, too. So to answer your question, you have to do an MRI biopsy if the only way you can "see" the suspicious area is on MRI.  (For me, the MRI showed two areas but the mammo showed only one of them.) Please keep in mind that MRI is very sensitive, and can show false positives.  One of the ways to keep the false positive rate down is to have the MRI done during the beginning of your period - I've forgotten exactly which days it's supposed to be between, so ask your Dr.!!!! So, if you want to have an MRI, take your period into account when you think about the schedule. Calcifications are tiny bits of calcium that can form for various reasons, one of those reasons being cancerous cells.  The calcium deposits can often be seen on mammo. MRI measures....blood uptake, I think.  Cancerous cells absorb more, probably because they're growing faster than normal cells (I'm guessing).  MRI won't see calcium deposits, but it will highlight cells that are unusually active. Sometimes surgeons do these biopsies, sometimes radiologists do.  Both of my biopsies were done by radiologists. I would also think about doing the BRCA genetic test, that takes 2-3 weeks for results to come back and you usually have to see a genetic counselor for it.  A breast surgeon should be able to recommend a genetics specialist. Sorry you have to go through this at all, hoping it's all benign for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 07:37AM sweatyspice wrote: Me:  Mammogram with calcs, stereotactic mammo biopsy - positive for DCIS. Ran into the "to MRI or not to MRI" controversy - after 3 different consults, ended up having the MRI. MRI showed another area of concern.  MRI guided biopsy.  More DCIS. Sooo..... As others have said, the MRI procedure itself was, for me, easier/less painful than the mammo biopsy.  No tugging and pulling for an hour to get my breast in position with the MRI. If you search, somewhere online there are instructional videos, I think by the equipment manufacturer, on how to perform an MRI biopsy.  They describe the whole thing, if you're interested. As I remember it, the process was longer then the original MRI scan, they slide you in, they slide you out, they slide you in, they slide you out, etc.  I've blocked out the details of how many times and why - that sort of info would be on the videos I mentioned. Tylenol is OK (picky about the pain relievers b/c some of them cause blood thinning and that will worsen healing, but Tylenol doesn't do that so it's approved for post-biopsy), Valium (or similar) beforehand is OK.   Ice and sports/compression bra. Wishing the best of luck and benign results!

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 06:28AM - edited Feb 18, 2010 06:54AM by sweatyspice Hey Mazy, Thank you for your kind words.  Your reply made me realize that I may not have been entirely clear.  One of the points I really wanted to make was that when someone posts in the DCIS forum about their experience with chemo, or mastectomy plus rads, it's not relevant b/c it's not how our disease is treated.  But if you've just been diagnosed w/DCIS you don't know that yet, and reading that sort thing will be upsetting for no reason. If DCIS comes back, half the time it will come back as an invasive cancer.  So the worry factor after active treatment ends is probably similar to what ladies with invasive disease experience.   Once again, all my best to the invasive girls!

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 06:45PM - edited Feb 2, 2010 06:46PM by sweatyspice Different situation:  I had two cancerous areas in the same breast - multicentric disease.  Normally the standard of care is mastectomy, but I fought against it.  I ended up having a double lumpectomy combined with a reduction and lift (and a reduction/lift to match on the healthy side). The radiation oncologist said she wouldn't treat me b/c after the smushing around of the tissue in the reduction/lift procedure, she wouldn't know where the involved areas had been.  So, as a solution, my surgeon planned to leave clips in as markers for the rads people. It's only been a few days since surgery, so I can't comment on long-term pain. I'm not sure why they'd do that for a mastectomy, but hopefully there's a good reason.

My 82 yr old mother has a 3cm breast mass she is actively ignoring.  My BS said it's not uncommon for women in her age group to refuse surgery, and if the patient is in that group and has a hormone sensitive cancer, she'll often give them antihormonals and that's it.  BS also said that at that age, cancers are often slow-growing and the antihormonals would slow them down further.
Posts.Title: My 85 yr. old Mom angeljoy angeljoy

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2010 09:51PM sweatyspice wrote: I noticed this thread through "Active Topics" and feel the need to try to speak for some of my newly diagnosed, "is it or isn't it cancer, what the hell is happening to me?" Stage 0 sisters: I can certainly understand why Stage 3 ladies would get pissed off by well meaning but clueless earlier stage advice.  On the flip side, ladies with invasive cancer often post what I'm sure they see as helpful advice in the DCIS forum. Unfortunately, many times that advice stirs up more confusion and fear than necessary. So:  Very rarely, if ever, will DCIS involve chemo.  If you have a mastectomy for DCIS, very rarely if ever will you also have radiation. If you have a lumpectomy for DCIS, you will probably have radiation (but if your grade is low enough and your DCIS is small enough you might be really lucky and escape rads).  Also, if you have a lumpectomy for DCIS, many surgeons consider SNB optional.  If the pathology came back with an unfortunate invasive surprise, you'd go back for the SNB in a second surgery.  (SNB is standard with mastectomy though, b/c you can't go back in.) Tamoxifen and ... I think that other one for post-menopausal women (I'm forgetting the name) are the only hormonals approved. I can see how DCIS might not even seem like cancer to a woman with invasive disease.  But telling us you think so gets us pretty riled up.  This was not a surgery I ever wanted to have. Much love to the higher stages.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 08:30AM - edited Mar 17, 2010 08:38AM by sweatyspice I had a very large lumpectomy combined with a reduction and lift, and a reduction and lift on the other side to match. I had multicentric disease, so the standard of care for me was a mastectomy but I couldn't go through with it.  Due to the location of the areas of my DCIS and the fact that I was large breasted, I was able to have the surgery I did. Double lumpectomy was another option but all the surgeons were concerned that they wouldn't get clean margins, and that even if they did the cosmetic result would be bad.  I ended up with 4mm and 7mm margins from the DCIS, but my path report showed residual LCIS and ADH (or is it ALH? I'm too lazy to look right now) and ADH (or ALH) in the breast we thought was healthy.  I feel like a recurrence waiting to happen but I'm not ready to part with my breasts unless/until I really do get a recurrence.  So, after thinking about it, I'm not going to fight the rads & Tamox. As far as the dread is concerned, I was always terrified of BC so my stress level hasn't really changed much. (When I was a little girl I lived with my Mom who had divorced and moved back in with her parents.  I saw my grandmother have a mastectomy & then die of bone mets in the late 1960's.  A very long time ago and I know treatment has changed significantly, but I was VERY young and impressionable.)   I'm BRCA negative.    What I'm most afraid of is the physical mutilation, and I'm not going to do that to myself unless/until I have no other choice.
Posts.Title: Stage 0 options ambyrp Kimmie4

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 01:27PM - edited Mar 20, 2010 02:05PM by sweatyspice I had the unfortunate yearly screening mammo in June 09, the diagnostic mammos and then biopsy in July 09.  Got path results in early August - DCIS.  Second opinion and then third opinion and then MRI which found second area of concern.  MRI biopsy, by now it's September.  More DCIS, and the plan changes from lumpectomy to mastectomy, freak out time.  Took another 2 weeks to schedule the BRCA test (the genetics people were only in the office part time and their schedule was pretty booked) and then 3 weeks to get results (insurance snag).  I'd guess it was November before I had all the information, then I was just trying to put a surgical team together I felt comfortable with.   Consulted with a BUNCH of surgeons, finally had surgery January 28th, 2010. I'd mention that all along the way, the surgeons I saw told me I had time to make a decision from a medical standpoint and that they were only concerned about the stress level and my mental health - with one very notable exception.  One breast surgeon who I saw at the end got VERY angry with me for dragging it out so long, he was concerned about the cancer turning invasive while I procrastinated. So, I delayed for several months - and it was longer than I would have liked it to be, but that's how long it took for me to meet a BS and PS team I felt good about, a procedure I felt OK about (I ended up not having a mastectomy in the end - I had a double lumpectomy combined with a reduction and lift, plus a reduction and lift in the healthy breast), and schedule everything.  My final pathology was still DCIS.   Because everything ended up going well, I don't regret the waiting. BUT - if there was really a concern about invasion, or if more of the surgeons felt that I needed to have surgery NOW and stop dilly dallying, well....that's a whole other story, and one that's outside my experience.  In that case, I probably would NOT have waited so long. Wishing you the best of luck, and congrats on your upcoming wedding!

Posts.Title: is it possible to go through rads more than once? tovahsmom sweatyspice

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 05:40AM - edited Apr 18, 2010 06:12AM by sweatyspice Why removal was such a tough decision for me: When I was a young girl in the late 1960's, I lived with my divorced mom and her parents (she'd moved back home).  My grandmother had a radical mastectomy and later died (it seems from bone mets).  I saw the pain, the scars, it was just hideous and deeply frightening.  Some part of little girl me "knew" this would be my destiny. I know that's wholly emotional, not rational in the least, and that mastectomy has changed drastically in the last 40 years.  It's just NOT the same procedure in 2010 that it was in 1965.  But the deep emotional imprint was there, and I was utterly freaked out. I'm also middle aged and single, and really, I'd like to have sex again before I die.  I don't have a DH standing my my side telling me how much he loves me and only cares that I live through it.  So there's the dating issue.  Plus, my breasts have always been VERY important to me sexually. I was very, very reluctant to let that go. I was also diagnosed with a stage 0 cancer.  That was another emotional component.  Something about it being caught so early made me go to "I'm going to mutilate my body by amputating my breasts for THIS measly pissant level of disease?" From the beginning, I always saw it as amputation and mutilation. Based on my presentation and pathology, it was standard of care.  It was explained to me, by a lot more than one BS, that if I did not have a mastectomy I would be looking at a much higher recurrence rate than average. But every time I thought about having the mastectomy I wanted to throw up. I Just Couldn't Do It. I ended up not doing it.  Now I have much smaller breasts, am in the middle of radiation treatment, and will take Tamoxifen for 5 years.  I think of this as "bonus time" with my breasts.  I can always have a mastectomy later if there IS a recurrence, something I half-expect.  Should that come to pass, especially if the recurrence is invasive, yes, there's a good chance I'll regret not having done mastectomy the first time and getting it over with.  But at the time, I just couldn't. I had a consult with a rad onc while I was trying to decide what to do, and told her if the course of disease was short, say two weeks, I'd rather be dead in two weeks and call it a life than have a numb "thing" on my chest for the rest of a long life.  She said "that's very interesting."  HA!  So, I fall into the "largely ornamental and serve no function" category.  Maybe I'm "vain."  But you asked for reasons and those are mine. If, when you think of mastectomy - even knowing about the loss of sensation, the potential complications, etc etc etc - if it gives you a sense of relief, it might be right for you.  As I said, every time I thought about it all I wanted to do was puke.

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2010 12:08PM sweatyspice wrote: If she had a small amount of low grade DCIS, big margins, and isn't young, radiation isn't ncessarily required.   Skipping rads is controversial.  It depends on the Dr's viewpoint and depends on the patient and her particular pathology even more.
Posts.Title: breast cancer and no radiation? sherry2007 sueUK

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 02:33PM sweatyspice wrote: You'll never know "for sure" that it's all DCIS until after your surgery, I woke up many mornings wondering if today was the day I'd pushed it too far.  It's a matter of what risk level you can tolerate and what your Dr's are saying. I'd also mention that when I was thinking mastectomy, I was also thinking immediate DIEP reconstruction - which made scheduling more difficult.  Even in November, with that as a plan I was looking at a January surgery. I just re-read your original post  - with a lat flap, yes, you're probably looking at a scheduling delay. So, you're having the MRI biopsy April 2?  You probably won't have results for another week.  And it seems like you already know you have 2 areas of DCIS and have accepted that you're looking at a mastectomy and reconstruction.....so the MRI biopsy shouldn't change your surgical planning.  I'm not even sure why they want to delay to DO the MRI, precisely because it won't change the surgical plan....unless it's because they're afraid it's invasive....but if it's not going to change the surgery, who cares?  They'd have that info from the surgical pathology report.  Frankly, I don't understand why they're putting you through this biopsy. In any case, if you do have the MRI, by the time you get the biopsy results it will be mid April and I don't see any reason not to wait 2 weeks, get married and enjoy yourself.  I can't imagine a few weeks making much of a difference, but again, I'd ask my Dr. My personal opinion is to book the June 15th date NOW, or whatever the first surgery date you can get is.  You can always change it for a later date, and maybe you'll be able to get an earlier date if there's a cancellation.  If you delay in booking anything, the earliest available date will soon be July.  I lived that one. I don't know why they suspect the third area is invasive, my hunch is that it's just more DCIS, but I'm not a Dr.  If it's just because it wasn't visible on ultrasound, well, none of my DCIS was visible on ultrasound - so I'm not taking 'invisible on ultrasound' alone as convincing evidence that it's invasive.  Maybe there's more to it than that.... I'm starting radiation in a few weeks, and as much as I'd rather not have anything to do with radiation, I'm less afraid of it than I was the surgery.  So yes, I hope the worst is behind me!  I guess I'll find out soon enough. Thanks, and again, best wishes to you!

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 05:46AM sweatyspice wrote: MRDRN - Margins only come into play with a "definitive" surgery, not a core biopsy.  It's intended to make sure all the nasty was removed.  In a core biopsy they're not trying to remove all of it, they're just trying to determine what the unknown item is. But your grade should be on the biopsy report.

Posts.Title: "Are you waiting for me to die, or what?" CoolBreeze lexislove

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 05:18AM sweatyspice wrote: The original poster has been diagnosed with DCIS.  As long as her final pathology remains pure DCIS, she should not need chemo as chemo is not given for DCIS. I also have DCIS.  Some surgeons have suggested nipple-sparing and I've discussed the option.  one said something like "all the ducts lead to the nipple.  After a mastectomy, you won't be having mammograms in that breast anymore and if you have a recurrence, the only way you'll know is when it's palpable, when you can feel it.  By that time, it won't be caught early, it will be invasive cancer, and it's not worth the risk to keep a nipple." Now, I don't know if what this surgeon said was true, or how many other breast surgeons would agree with her, but there's definitely a difference between a DCIS recurrence and an invasive recurrence.... Of course there will always be a post-mastectomy risk of recurrence in the scar tissue or any remaining breast tissue, but that risk can't be eliminated. So...I'd have a serious talk about recurrence risk with a surgeon, or two, or three - see what most of them say.
Posts.Title: question about nipple sparing mastectomy cl00 LISAMG

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 10:32PM sweatyspice wrote: Had to add:  Had another convo about nip sparing (and a zillion other things) with a different surgeon, who totally disagreed with the comments in my post above. I wish I'd gone to med school, cause the Drs all disagree and I don't have any idea who to believe.
